Award.AwardTitle: Robust Design and Control of Multi-Axis Thin-film Piezoelectric Scanning Actuators for Deep-Tissue Endoscopic Microscopy

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The focus of this project is to model and control piezoelectric thin-film actuators for miniature imaging instruments. Certain high-resolution imaging techniques can penetrate relatively deeply into biological tissue. Use of this ability with living organisms through small handheld and/or endoscopic tools requires precise control of novel micro-scale actuators, such as those based on the piezoelectric material lead-zirconate-titanate (PZT), deposited as thin-film on silicon wafers. Compact mathematical models will be developed to describe thin-film PZT behavior at varying operating frequencies and amplitudes. This will be incorporated into dynamic models of actuator structural motion subject to variation in actuator manufacturing, and techniques from the field of robust control will be used to design actuators that are comparatively insensitive to fabrication errors and piezoelectric material variability. Finally, feedback controllers based on the preceding models will be designed to regulate actuator motion using on-board sensing measurements.

The proposed work will have broad impact by supporting miniaturization of deep-tissue optical microscopy systems to an endoscope-compatible form factor. These instruments would enable a variety of scientific and clinical activities regarding topics such as systems biology, cancer, and allergic disease. Better understanding of thin-film PZT behavior could also improve a variety of micro-scale actuators based on piezoelectric materials, such as nanopositioners, micro-robots, and optical scanning mirrors. Design for robustness could help reduce susceptibility of microtechnologies to poor yield or limited performance due to processing and environmental variability. Educationally, undergraduate researchers will be heavily involved in experimental testing of prototype devices and control system implementation, through engineering internship programs targeting women and underrepresented minorities. Support would also be used to develop and implement engineering design and experimentation activities in the University of Michigan Detroit Area Pre-College Engineering Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined the dynamics and control of micro-robots in terrestrial locomotion over unknown terrain.  At their smallest, in sizes of 2 to 5 mm in length as manufactured by microelectromechanical system (MEMS) fabrication processes, such walking robots have very limited capacity for sensing their environment or even their own motions.  Thus, strategies are needed for selection of inputs to the robot legs that will lead to effective locomotion of the robots.  Because robot appendage motion is limited compared to biological organisms, this often depends on operating the robot near its legs vibratory resonance, which can lead to complex dynamic behaviors when coupled with foot-ground impact dynamcis. This work examined techniques for modeling robot locomotion, using limited on-chip sensor information to improve robot knowledge of its surroundings or locomotion effectiveness, and coupling miniature battery energy to the robot legs in an optimal fashion.  Experiments were performed with both micro-scale (2-10 mm total length) and meso-scale (25-80 mm total length) robot prototypes.

Intellectual Merit:

This award has supported development of comprehensive mathematical models for elastic micro-robots performing terrestrial locomotion.  As miniature robots often rely on elastic bending of their appendages rather than jointed motion of larger-scale robots, their interaction with underlying terrain can lead to complicated vibratory responses, which may enhance or restrict effective robot locomotion.   The models generated in this work can be used to simulate hypothetical robot geometries and control strategies.   For example, simulated swarm optimization of micro-robot velocity allows teams of robots to improve their overall locomotion speed with only small amounts of individual robot on-chip information.  In addition, this work provided opportunities to improve manufacturing capabilities for millimeter-scale robots through integration of piezoelectric and polymer microstructures, and to enhance understanding of miniature battery dynamics when driving fast transient motions of miniature robots.

Broader Impact:

The results above provide opportunities to increase payload capacity, range-of-motion, resilience, and efficiency of millimeter-scale micro-robots.  As robot mobility improves, it increases the potential utility of such robots to perform tasks in applications such as exploration, emergency response, national security, and infrastructure monitoring.   Within the field of dynamics and control, dynamic modeling strategies may be applicable to other microdevices dependent on intermittent contact events, such as microswitches and rotary micromotors.   Educationally, this award helped support several undergraduate and graduate research assistants, and presentation of micro-robotic advances to the general public through various outreach activities.
